content.description: This problem is characterized by the big flake/jug about midway up.
content.location:
This route is on the south side of the Cheeseburger Boulder to the right of

Cheeseburger

.

content.description: Start as for the unnamed V8 on the southeast face of The Egg Boulder (a large jug). Rather than climbing out the bulge to the left, climb straight up on crimps, and top out on slopers.
content.location: This ascends the Southeast face of The Egg Boulder.

content.description: On the left side of the main face of Solitary Spirit, start on a sidepull/pinch and right hand sloper. Use only holds on the face, not around the arete. This is very crimpy with lots of tension. It is fun!
content.location: It is on the left side of Solitary Spirit.

content.description:
Start with your hands matched in a heavily chalked, incut hold on the far ride side of Solitary Spirit. Get established on the slab (a difficult, reachy move for me) before slabbing it up and topping out.

An easier variation of this problem (and decent warm-up if needed) starts at a high rail up and to the right of the start holds and traverses over the slab before topping out.
content.location: It is on the lower angle, right side of Solitary Spirit.

content.description: A short but powerful line on "The Egg" boulder.  Start low on a jug and climb the crimp face, trending left at the top to gain a huge horn for the top out.
content.location: It's on the southeast face of The Egg, a boulder just left of the Big Cat wall.  If you're looking at this boulder from the Big Cat, it's on the right side.  There is also a V8 that climbs out of the bulge to the left of this problem.

content.description: Start at the base of the right arete in the Corridor in the main area.  A combination of squeezing and face work move you up the leftward trending arete, with a tree-back-scrath (so good!) at about 2/3rd height.  A solid arete training route.
content.location: Right end of corridor, up the leftward-trending arete.

content.description:
This route is on the warm-up boulder. Start on the right side from a layback stance and work your way left via crimps. Long reaches make this route easy, but sticking to the crimps requires great footwork.

There is a flat landing below the warm-up boulder. It has an easy walk-off.
content.protection: A pad and spotter are optional.
content.location:
This is on the warm-up boulder near

Hyperion Arete

.

content.description:
Climb the right of the two large cracks with a layback start. It has a high topout, but it is solid.

The other crack is also V0 and not quite as good.
content.location: It is in the middle of the Prow, which is a minute or two uphill from the trail after the third set of switchbacks. The third set of switchbacks is much larger than the first two.

content.description: Take the obvious, right-angling crack up using plentiful edges.
content.location: This is on the left Paulaner Wall, which is just off the trail to the north at the start of the third set of switchbacks. The third set of switchbacks is much larger than the first two.

content.description:
Start to the left of

Hamburger

on a little horn (chalked up generally).  Stand up and extend to the Gaston inside the crack up the left.  Keep your body off of the protruding rock to the left of the problem.  Work your hands up the crack and slap to the left of the problem about 2-3 feet up, work your feet and make your move towards a protruding horn along the top (well-defined).  Keep your feet and apply your technique to get over the top.
content.protection: Great landing, just be carefull of the outcrop of rock at the bottom.  Excellent space to pile the matts (if needed).  Just a good spot and a pad is all you need.
content.location:
Sharing the same block as

Hamburger

.

content.description:
Start the classic

Center Route

(in the Corridor), but break off left into the blankish face.  There are no juggy rails here!  Houdini your way up vertical and sultry face.  It requires a solid jump above the technique required for the standard route.  Good, ++.
content.location:
Use the same start as the classic

Center Route

.

content.description: Lager goes up the left side of the face and arete through some questionable rock. Top out onto the ridge.
content.location: This is on the left side of Paulaner Wall, which is just off the trail to the north at the start of the third set of switchbacks. The third set of switchbacks is much larger than the first two.

content.description: Climb up the middle of the face. Pull a long-ish move in the middle, then gain the triangular shelf. Move up to the rounded lip, and traverse right.
content.location: This is on the left Paulaner Wall, which is just off the trail to the north at the start of the third set of switchbacks. The third set of switchbacks is much larger than the first two.

content.description: We started low perched on a decent foot ledge almost sitting. Starting with a left hand on an incut sidepull and right hand on one of the slopers. Use a seam and slopers to make upward progress, eventually gaining a stance standing on the starting slopers, utilizing the mini-roof as an undercling. It was at this stance that we then used a somewhat unobvious rail to break right using decent but lichen covered crimps to top out over the bad landing.
content.location:
This problem is located on the Big Cat Boulder. It starts on the right arete of the obvious double arete feature and two problems to the right of

Big Cat

.

content.description: Climb out this overhanging block using both aretes.
content.location: This leaning pillar is one of the first you'll see as you approach the Lion's Den from the West.

content.description: This is a short arete problem with good right hand holds but not much for the left.  It requires some balance.
content.location: This is in the main area, just above the corridor.

content.description:
This route climbs the clean slab just above a short, blocky section on the band of rock before

Lager

and

Pilsner

on the Paulaner Wall. Some of the grades for problems in this area seem off from the Gillett guidebook to the St. Vrain.
content.location:
This is easily identified as the clean panel of grey stone before hitting

Lager

and

Pilsner

.

content.description: Start off center boulder below the horizontal cracks, directly below a scar on the top of the boulder.  You start off with a generous undercling and slap for the first crack with high feet - you can bump up with a series of slopey little finger holds or  just go big depending on your ape index - match on the crack and move to the left of the line, get your feet up high and slap for the next crack up and to the right.  keep your feet moving  high and make use of the scar if needed, there is a generous top-out.  Feet are very important on this problem, without good feet you will be wasting a lot of unnecessary energy.
content.protection: It has a great landing: flat, soft ground with plenty of space to lay the pads down.
content.location:
From the main bouldering area, travel east about 50 yards, and you will see a large boulder on your right (from

Hyperion Arete

, you can see Hamburger through the trees). If you are standing at Cheeseburger Boulder or in and around The Boneyard, you have to turn around and go about 30 yards or so back.

content.description: Start low in a finger seam, slap the face, and crank to a crystal and the top.
content.location: This lies on the Northwest face of the Egg Boulder.

content.description: Unforgettable name for a stardard warm up. Start with feet on the slopey bulge and hands on crystals.  Move up to the fingers crack with a good right foot on the slab and a prayer.  Top out up the crack and exit right.
content.location:
Immediately behind the start of the classic

Center Route

in the Corridor at the main area.

content.description:
Choss Boss is located on the warm up boulder. This makes for an excellent topout for the

PW Traverse

. There are a few differing variations and starts on this boulder. This area has great landings and easy downclimbs.
content.location: This is on the warm up boulder.

content.description: Start on two crimps, move up to another set of crimps, then fire high and left for the first of two sloper slots.  More moves get you to the hold at the lip and the tricky, holdless topout.  Absolutely CLASSIC for the grade--will keep you coming back for another bite!
content.protection: Pads and a spotter on the rock ledge for moral support topping out.
content.location:
This is a bit beyond and left of the main area (approximately 50 meters) and about 20 meters from

Hamburger

.  It has an absolutely unmistakable, "Cheeseburger" looking face!

content.description: Start from the right-facing dihedral, and move up the staircase of protruding, horizontal holds that take up all the way to the top of the classic and gently overhanging problem.  Running laps on this as a warm up is reason enough to visit the Lion's Den!
content.location: It is in the center of the face of the Corridor in the main area.

content.description: Start from two underclings and a good foot rail and move up into the downward facing dihedral on a combination of crimps and sloper dishes to the finger slot near the topout.  Not all that pretty to look at, but really good movement and a bit tricky for the grade.
content.protection: Pad on the boulder at the base.
content.location: Big Kitty Corner is on the rock just down and left of the boulder with the classic "Tagger" and "Tigger" problems.  The start of the problem is easily identified by a small boulder on the ground at its base which is easily covered with a pad.  Not to be confused with another problem that starts a few feet left and moves up to a hollow, brittle, detached, flake thingy.

content.description: This is THE classic problem at the Lion's Den.  It's a beautiful highball face with some cool features.  Crux is about two-thirds the way up the route.  Sustained, technical moves on great rock.
content.protection: This thing is pretty freaking tall.  The landing is nice, but it may be a good idea to stack pads as a fall from the crux is about a 12-footer.
content.location: You can't really miss it.  It's one of the first problems you will see as you enter the Lion's Den from the trail.

content.description: Start in the hole formed by multiple boulders and make a hard move up to the bottom of the crescent-shaped feature.  Work up til you are standing in the crescent and from here move out right onto the face before the good holds at the lip (knowing how to handjam is helpful for the topout).  A fun highball with three distinct sections that is safe with pads and spotters.
content.protection: Pads needed in the hole, and on the slab rock to the right of the problem and at the same height as the crescent feature.  A spotter in the hole and on the slab to the right are ideal.
content.location:
In the central area right, to the left of the beautiful and high wall with the unmistakeable crack line on the right side of its face (forgot the name of this problem).  The topout to the problem is also directly in front of the standard downclimb of the "

Center Route

" in the Corridor.
